text: Opening shot - High angle on Lincoln along small bay with boats. Ext. Bar - Waist to full figure Pan Right to Left.  Detec comes out eating pizza, looking around.  He crosses stree and stops against wall of impasse Michael. He looks O.S. left, His POV - L.S. of Lincoln behind fishing nets. Waist shot of Detective looking and eating. M.S. of Lincoln. C.S. of Detective looking O.S. Left. Pan Right to Left with Charnier coming out from Fonfon wi three friends and they walk to the Lincoln. Pan Left to Right with Lincoln passing in front of the Detective.
High angle from balcony.  Zoom on Detective seated at the cafe, reading a newspaper. Cut on Lincoln along sidewalk of the cafe, then zoom back discover Detective seated.

Low angle from stairs Rue des Repenties and Pan Left to Right to Rue Sainte Francoise following the Detective. Pan Left to Right with Detective from Rue des Repenties t Rue Baussenque. Low angle between Rue des Moulins and Rue des Accoules wi Detective passing by. Ext. Rue du Panier - The Detective comes out from the bak camera Right and starts to climb up Rue des Moulins with bread.
High angle - on No. 50 Rue des Moulins.  Pan Left to Righ with Detective coming up the street with his bread and go inside his house, starting to open his letter-box.

High angle - complete reverse.  As the Detective starts t open his letter-box in B.G. a hand pointing a gun moves i foreground and blows off half of the French Detective's h with the first shot. Cut to Nicoli C.S. who just fired.

A large man in a Santa Claus suit and white beard is entertaining a group of black children.  He leads them in the singing of a Christmas Carol (Hark the Herald Angels Sing).  The man is DETECTIVE FIRST GRADE JIMMY DOYLE.  Hi attention is split between the children and the activity inside the bar.

The place is crowded with mid-day drinkers.  Dimly outlin at the far end of the bar are TWO BLACK MEN involved in s kind of transaction in which a package is exchanged for money.  As the transaction seems to be completed, cut to

Santa Claus (DOYLE) starts to ring his big Christmas bell above the singing.  The bell is a signal to DETECTIVE SEC GRADE BUDDY RUSSO.  At this moment RUSSO is in the clothe of a hot dog vendor and is in fact working behind a hot d wagon.  At the ringing of DOYLE's bell he takes off his apron, leaves the wagon, and runs toward the bar.
(as RUSSO passes him)
The guy in the brown coat.
RUSSO enter the bar on the run.  He stops and looks over room.

There are TWENTY or THIRTY MEN at the bar, at least TEN a wearing brown coats!  The TWO MEN involved in the deal se RUSSO and start to run.  One (THE BUYER) takes off out of the back door.  The other (THE PUSHER) jumps over the bar and heads for the front entrance.
THE PUSHER dashes out past Santa Claus (DOYLE).  RUSSO follows him and all three give chase.

THREE FIGURES running down a New York tenement alley, the first in flight, the others in pursuit.  We pick up the incredible clutter of such an alley, mounts of rusting be cans, paper bags of garbage bulging and ripping open, old bed springs, burned out mattresses, etc.

Close shot of BLACK PUSHER tripping on the tangle of tras going up against the wall in his stumble, face toward the camera, and the figures of RUSSO and DOYLE leaping upon h from off-camera.  There is a blur or fast struggle as DOY and RUSSO try to get his arms and put him against the wal BLACK PUSHER writhes loose and we close in on a knife in hand, plunging rapidly into RUSSO'S left forearm.

Son of a bitch! The words are both warning and a grunt of pain.  As RUSSO takes the blade and utters the words, we simultaneously g to DOYLE crouching and snatching his .38 out of the right ankle holster.

Close shot of DOYLE and the BLACK PUSHER, DOYLE pistol- whipping him into submission with three lightening chops the gun to the PUSHER'S head.  DOYLE continues to beat th man mercilessly into submission.

3-shot of BLACK PUSHER sitting between DOYLE and RUSSO. DOYLE is at the wheel.  BLACK PUSHER is sitting on his hands, wrists manacled behind him, his head down and drip blood onto the jacket and the canary-yellow turtleneck. three are breathing hard.
What's your name, asshole?
Fuck you, Santa Claus! DOYLE hits him across the face.
Your name is Willie Craven. BLACK PUSHER doesn't look up.
Who's your connection, Willie? What's his name? No response.
Who killed the old Jew in the laundromat? BLACK PUSHER's brow furrows, looks up just a little.
I don't...
Ever pick your feet in Poughkeepsie?
What?
Did you ever pick your feet in Poughkeepsie?
I don't know what you're talkin' about.
Were you ever in Poughkeepsie?
No... yeah...
Did you ever sit on the edge of the bed, take off your socks and stick your fingers between your toes?
Man, I'm clean.
You made three sales to your roaches back there.  We had to chase you through all this shit and you tell me you're clean?
Who stuck up the laundromat?
How about that time you were picking your feet in Poughkeepsie? The BLACK PUSHER'S eyes go to RUSSO in panic, looking for relief from the pressure of the inquisition.
(in pain)
You better give me the guy who got the old Jew or you better give me something or you're just a memory in this town.
That's a lot o' shit.  I didn't do nothin'. The BLACK PUSHER's eyes are on DOYLE, frozen in confusion and fear.

You put a shiv in my partner.  Know what that means?  All winter I gotta listen to him gripe about his bowling scores.  Now I'm gonna bust your ass for those three bags - then I'm gonna nail you for pickin' your feet in Poughkeepsie.

location: HEADQUARTERS NARCOTICS BUREAU OF THE NYPD 12 OLD SLI

text: DOYLE and RUSSO standing side by side on the front steps the old First Precinct on the Lower East Side of Manhatta RUSSO has his overcoat over his shoulders as a cape.  The sleeve of his left arm is rolled up over a blood-stained bandage on the left forearm.
Havin' trouble?  You're a dumb guinea.
How'd I know he had a knife.
Never trust a nigger.
He coulda been white.
Never trust anybody.  You goin' sick?

Not a chance. RUSSO nods in acceptance of the remark.  The easy, synica rapport between them is obvious: they are partners in a business where somebody is always getting hurt and pain i part of the inventory.
Let's popeye around the Chez for a half hour, catch the end of the show and a couple drinks.
Some other time Jimmy, I'm beat. DOYLE reaches into the right side pocket of BUDDY's suitc for a cigarette and matches.  He lights up two in the pau sticks one in RUSSO's mouth.
Come on -- one drink.  Whatta you say?
Drink this.
Whip it out.
THE FRENCH CONNECTION

Titles over a close shot of a chorus line, with lots of t and ass and lean, long legs in a brassy blare of music. zoom back to the area where DOYLE and RUSSO are beginning occupy a table.  RUSSO takes the seat on the right, eyes immediately on all that ginch, while DOYLE standing, give their order.  We do not hear the dialogue but DOYLE asks RUSSO what he wants BUDDY looks up and says "Cinzano." DO turns and says "Two of these." DOYLE slips into the chair opposite RUSSO and the titles roll on.  Unlike RUSSO who concentrating on the girls, DOYLE is digging the room and the people who occupy the tables in it, as if he is the s of man who cannot relax until he knows who is around him, why they are there.

A long view from DOYLE's position of the room, a quick certain survey that stumbles twice; on laughter that seem too raw and then over a flurry of activity by WAITERS and CAPTAINS serving a table on the main floor.  DOYLE's attention is apprehended by the noise and activity that emanate from the same large table.
I make at least two junk connections at that table in the corner.  The guy is the stripe combo, I know him too.
Hey, I thought we come for a drink.
A long view of the table with DOYLE and RUSSO very close foreground, left and right.  DOYLE is leaning on an elbow
Who is that guy?
Policy man in Queens.

What about the last of the big-time spenders.  You make him? RUSSO's eyes come off the show.  It is a direct line from DOYLE's gaze to the round, ruddy and arrogant face of SAL BOCA, the apparent host of the table of EIGHT MEN AND WOM the Men in dinner jackets with ties tucked under the coll of blue or white lace-trimmed shirts, the Women in a mixt of pant suits and Catskills cocktail party dresses, their hair coiffed towers.
No, you?
Hunh-uh.  Check the bread.  He spreads it like the Russians are in Jersey.
He probably sells insurance.  Owns a chicken farm in Hackensack.

Zoom in slowly on SAL as he deals tips and orders.  Throu DOYLE's eyes, we go from Guest to Guest at SAL's table, taking apart their manners and styles as they talk and laugh, lost in the show chatter.
DOYLE finishing his drink, still looking at the table.
Dig who's just come over.  The creep on the end.
The camera pans down the table to dig the "creep on the e
Jewish Lucky from the Bronx... He don't look the same without a number across his chest.
DOYLE close in right profile, SAL's table in the far blur background.
Whatta you say we wait and give him a tail?
Give who a tail?
The greaser with the blonde.
What for -- you wanna play Hide the Salami with his old lady?
Come on -- just for fun --

The view from the back seat of DOYLE's car.  DOYLE is at wheel, RUSSO packed uncomfortably into the corner at DOYL right.  Seventy-five yards away on the other side of the street the canopied entrance of the Club.  A Continental parked in front of the club.  The DRIVER leaning on a fen talking with the DOORMAN.  DOYLE frisks his own pockets f a cigarette, coming up with a collection of laundry slips crumpled notes, toothpicks and matches.

One of the slips of paper catches his eye as he is going through the ritual of the cigarette mooch, a slip bearing the name of a girl.  His attention is really on the entra of the Club and both his conversation and the cigarette business are detached and incidental to the art of waitin through the stakeout.  He stuffs the cards back into his pocket.
Monica?  Who's Monica?
(handing him a cigarette)

A and A, that's all you're interested in -- Arrests and Ass. As soon as DOYLE has finished lighting the cigarette SAL his PARTY come bubbling out of the Club noisily, a little drunkenly.  SAL waves to the attentive DOORMAN. DOYLE close, leaning forward over the wheel to put his ha on the ignition key.  He does not turn it.  He is waiting for the cover of noise from the starting of SAL's car. RUSSO is turning the opposite corner of the car into a be his head back, arms across his chest.
Cloudy, I'll lay odds he takes us to Little Italy. DOYLE reaches under his seat for the straw surveillance hat - throws it up to read ledge of car.

I'm telling you, Popeye, he owns a bagel mine in the Bronx. A long view of the Club entrance.  SAL and ANGIE, a well- built "classy" blonde with good legs, get into their blac Mercury sedan.  The Mercury takes off towards First Avenu We hear DOYLE's car start and we move off after them on t last blink of tail-lights at the corner.

Cabs, Daily News and Times delivery trucks, bakery vans a a few cruising cabs, one or two passenger cars and a coas green and black police cruiser -- this is the 4:30 a.m. traffic through which DOYLE moves. A rear-window view of SAL and ANGIE BOCA, in animated conversation.  His head is turned toward her, his hand raised in a gesture.  ANGIE is sitting in a corner with h back to the door, in profile to the back window.

Her blonde head bobbles with laughter over some remark SA has made. A long overhead view of the two cars wheeling in and out the sparse traffic. Close shot of the license plate on BOCA's car. Close shot DOYLE staring at license plate, memorizing it.
BOCA and ANGIE exit restaurant, get into their car and dr off.  Hold for DOYLE's car as it passes through after the

Side close view of SAL turning south into Mott Street panning to pick up the Italian names on the candy stores, funeral parlors, bars, grocery stores, social clubs. A long view of SAL's car from the DOYLE-RUSSO auto, over shoulders of the two cops.  DOYLE is leaning on the wheel his car.  He's against the curb about 100 yards behind SA Medium close view of SAL in the middle of Mott Street, walking quickly toward the opposite side of the street, hands in the pocket of his white raincoat.  He glances ov his shoulder in the direction of DOYLE's car. Close of RUSSO who has come awake.  The smart-ass demeano has dropped away.  DOYLE turns to him and smiles.  This district is the heart of every illegal activity in New Yo Close rear view of DOYLE and RUSSO ducking down to the le of the dashboard, a reflex action.  He couldn't see them that distance, although SAL, lighted by his own headlight can be seen in the background walking around the cars, across the sidewalk and stopped at a recessed doorway. Medium close shot of SAL and partially visible FIGURE at doorway.  With another glance up the street, SAL takes something out of his raincoat pocket and steps up and int the doorway.
Close from the front of DOYLE and RUSSO low against the dashboard.
It's a drop! DOYLE's face, close, light smile.

Long view of SAL walking down the sidewalk quickly for ab a quarter of a block while the headlights of his car, wit ANGIE apparently driving, move up with him.  At another doorway, he looks back and then steps inside.
Long view of SAL's Mercury moving over Brooklyn Bridge. Close shot of the DOYLE-RUSSO car from RUSSO's side.  BUD now interested, watching.

Overhead view of cars circling block, first Mercury turni corner, then DOYLE's Ford. Long shot of the Mercury pulling up beside line of parked cars (as seen from DOYLE-RUSSO car) stopping and parking. Hold on Mercury as SAL and ANGIE get out of it.  SAL lock it up, and starting to walk toward a line of parked cars. Close shot from rear seat of DOYLE and RUSSO glancing at each other. SAL and ANGIE stop in the street beside beat-up white Dod Without a word they get in.  Hold as they get in, SAL sta and they begin to drive out of the spot. Close on DOYLE.

It's startin' to cook, Cloudy, my man is cookin'... A series of impressionist traveling shots of the white Do and DOYLE's Ford moving through Brooklyn Streets, picking street signs of areas. Medium close shot of the white Dodge pulling into the cur In near background, a candy-confectionery store.

Close shot of DOYLE and RUSSO in profile driving past the candy store as SAL and ANGIE open door and go in. Close shot of DOYLE and RUSSO parked.  DOYLE is looking i the rear-view mirror while BUDDY is turned around on the seat, looking out the rear window. A long shot, from the DOYLE-RUSSO viewpoint of the candy store.  The door is open, the street is deserted.  Lights are going on in the little shop.

Hold on the storefront as SAL appears, this time in a can store operator's smock over a white undershirt, baggy sla He's carrying a stack of newspapers.  Zoom in on SAL stac the Sunday Times and the Daily News on the rack in front the store as ANGIE appears in the doorway.  She's blackha now, the blonde wig gone, also wearing a grey cotton smoc over a plain skirt and sweater, holding a cup of coffee. hold on them for a beat, then
DOYLE and RUSSO close just looking at each other.  The lo says everything about the freak case they have stumbled i
1) Tight two shot then, 2) cut into blue prints.

En prolongeant les quais d'une trentaine de metres on pourra recevoir des unites d'une cargaison de 500 tonnes. 3) While he shows the extension, clean P.O.V. Of each qua 4) Dolly Left to Right with Notre-Dame in background.  Th fold the blue prints and moves.
Et combien d'hommes supplementaires?
Ca fera environ 10 hommes de plus par equipe.
Le Syndicat exigera un minimum de 12.
Quelle importance.  Ce qui compte pour moi c'est d'avoir un chantier qui puisse recevoir les plus grands bateaux du monde.
Dis moi vieille branche?  Comment fais tu pour rester si jeune avec la vie que tu menes?
Quelle vie Marcel?  J'ai plus rien foutu depuis que je suis descendu de ces cabines.
Pan Left to Right Lincoln driven by Jean with Charnier be

location: CASSIS CROSSROAD IN FRONT OF MARSEILLE SIGN POST

text: Lincoln passing by.
Pan Right to Left with Lincoln passing by.
Pan Right to Left with Lincoln arriving from main road to Villa.
Camera in front of garage where the Lincoln stops.  Charn comes out with gift and walks Right to Left.
Pan Left to Right with Charnier walking along terrace wit Cassis bay in B.G., and we discover his wife, Marie.  She gets up.  Dolly back.
Bonjour cherie. They kiss each other and walk arm in arm back to us.
Close 2-shot favouring her.  He gives her the gift.
Tu sais j'ai reflechi longuement a ton cadeau pour le voyage.  Je l'ai choisi moi-meme.  Tiens.
Je peux l'ouvrir tout de suite?
Si tu veux.
(opening the gift)
Oh Alain!  C'est merveilleux!  Tu me gates.  Je t'aime.  Attends, je vais te montrer moi aussi ce que j'ai achete.
Encore du sho ping!
L.S. Pan Right to left from under the trees following her she leaves Charnier to enter in the house.
C.S. of Charnier along the terrace.  He throws a fishing pole in the sea.
PAN RIGHT TO LEFT with Marie coming back with a new coat.
Regarde mon pecheur de baleine... Tu sais il va faire tres froid cet hiver.
Avec ca tu pourras le supporter.
Mais non, c'est pour toi.
Pour moi?
Regarde, il te va parfaitement bien!
Formidable!  Sans toi je m'habillerais encore en docker. (then, taking off coat)
Je suis passe voir Francoise.
Comment va-t-elle?
Je n'ai jamais vu tant de serenite. Elle m'a demande de tes nouvelles et si nous etions heureux.
Le sommes nous?
(he kisses her)
Non!

Complete Pan Left to Right with Lincoln passing in front Samaritaine cafe. Driver pulls out.  Charnier comes out from Lincoln and we follow him as he crosses Left to Right and jumps into the boat which moves out.
Back shot.  Charnier standing in the moving boat and smok as Marseille diminishes in B.G.
From the boat approaching Chateau d'If.

Pan Right to Left as Charnier gets out of boat and starts climb up. High angle thru first stone door with sea in B.G.  Charni comes up and turns Right to Left. High angle -- Pan Left to Right -- Low angle, with Charni coming up from 2nd arch to 3rd arch thru which we see the tower in B.G.
Pan Left to Right with Charnier arriving on terrace.
Nicoli back to us.  He turns left shoulder as we approach him.
Dolly back preceding Charnier and Nicoli after they meet Pan Left to Right to the Rotonde.
Ca a marche?
Au poil. They turn around.
Sale boulot.
Il fallait le faire.
Il est en retard.
Je crois qu'on fait une erreur de le prendre avec nous.
Une erreur!  C'est genial.  C'est une vedette a la television.  Il peut aller partout sans etre soupconne... En plus il a besoin de fric.
J'ai pas confiance en lui.
Sois gentil avec lui.  On ne sait jamais.  Il peut te faire travailler a la television.
Cut on Devereau arriving.  He sees them.
Pan Left to Right bringing Charnier and Nicoli towards Devereaux to finish in 3-shot.
Henri c'est gentil d'etre venu.  Je vous presente mon associe, Pierre Nicoli.  Henri Devereaux.
Enchante. (they shake hands)
Alain, j'ai reflechi a votre proposition et j'ai decide d'accepter.
SURVEILLANCE MONTAGE OF SAL BOCA's activities.  From time time DOYLE and RUSSO are visible, but their dialogue is f the most part VOICE OVER.

Various shots of SAL and ANGIE.  Several shots of DOYLE a RUSSO in the CANDY STORE: reading magazines, having lunch separately.  They are also seen in the LEATHER FACTORY across the street observing the CANDY STORE.  Several CHARACTERS enter the CANDY STORE from time to time and go into the BACK ROOM. Following are a series of cuts (MOS) to be used with the dialogue of RUSSO and DOYLE.
SAL counts the receipts.  Two or three CUSTOMERS in the B SAL removes a tray of Ziti from the oven.  ANGIE makes an order to go. SAL removes garbage from the back area.

Our friend's name is SALVATORE BOCA. They call him SAL.  He's a sweetheart.  He once was picked up on suspicion of armed robbery. Tried to hold up Tiffany's on Fifth Avenue!  In broad daylight!  Could have got two-and-a-half to five, but they wouldn't prosecute.  Also downtown they're sure he pulled off a contract on a guy named DeMarco.
SAL putting garbage into cans.  Pan and Zoom to DOYLE and RUSSO in window of FACTORY across the street.
ANGIE carries bowl of hard-boiled eggs from rear of store the front.
His old lady? ANGIE makes a tuna sandwich on a roll.  A cigarette dangl from her lips.  SAL is in BG at cash register with custom
Her name's Angie... Fast filly... she drew a suspended for shoplifting a year ago... only a kid, nineteen according to the marriage license. From front of store looking to back.

Yeah, nineteen goin' on fifty. What else? RUSSO is at counter eating lunch with three others... ANG serving.  She wears a sleeveless sweater; shows lots of t RUSSO digs... she digs him.  A wise guy comes in, goes to the back room.  SAL follows.
He's had the store a year an'a half... takes in a fast seven grand a year.
POV from FACTORY window... Two Wise Guys in big coats and hats pull up in a big car.  They enter store.
So what's he doin' with two cars and hundred dollar tabs at the Chez?

Angie shooting from back of store towards front.  The Two Wise Guys enter, go to Back Room.  SAL follows.  They clo door.  DOYLE is at the magazine counter in front.  He sit down with magazine.  Orders coffee.
The Merc's in his wife's name. Dodge belongs to his brother.
A heavy-faced, dirty looking man in a Sanitation Dept. uniform in a group of men practising with Sanitation truc
Lou... he's a trainee at the Sanitation School on Ward's Island. Served time a couple of years ago, on assault and robbery raps.
LOU pulls up.  As LOU picks up SAL.  They drive to variou buildings in Brooklyn.  One or the other gets out briefly then goes on.  DOYLE and RUSSO watch from DOYLE's car.
If that's not a drop or a pickup, I'll open a charge for you at Bloomingdale's.
Make it Alexander's, I like the toy department.
Toy wit' this will ya.
There's about a hundred years' parole time in there night or day. SAL arrives alone.  DOYLE and RUSSO in parked car across street.
They treat our boy like a king. Wonder why he don't bring his old lady? SAL flirts with the BARMAID.
There's your answer...
Restaurants, stores, etc.
Who's the greaser? With SAL and his FATHER.
It's his father. DOYLE and RUSSO in parked car.
I think we oughta burn him on suspicion.
Suspicion of what?
Makin' wine in the basement. (pause)
He looks like that wop stooge used to drive for the Fracisi brothers. LOU joins them.  He and SAL leave together after each kis and embraces the old man.
Lay off with that wop stuff, will you?
In the East 80's.  SAL exits.
That's the third time he come here this week.  You got anything on the building? DOYLE and RUSSO in parked car.
The building's clean.  I checked the tenant list -- Don Ameche, the actor lives there -- oh, and somebody else.  Do the name Joel Weinstock ring a bell?
Late day.  WEINSTOCK leaving building, nodding to doorman
You're kiddin' DOYLE and RUSSO in parked car.
No sir -- this is where Joel lives.
He was the bank on that shipment outta Mexico three years ago.
So I've heard.
SAL and ANGIE leaving.
Whatta you know -- he's takin' his wife out for a change. DOYLE and RUSSO in parked car.
Across street from Candy Store.  DOYLE and RUSSO at the printing machine.
(at leather printing machine)
Got a job for me when this is over, Mrs. Levene? They have a view of the Candy Store across street.  Vario people go in and out.  Next to DOYLE, at a stamping machi is MRS. LEVENE, the factory owner.
What are you fellows looking for? What do you want from that nice candy store?
We have reason to believe it's a front for the biggest counterfeiting operation in the country.
What?

That's right.  They're trying to steal the formula for Hershey bars -- DOYLE continues his work at the print-out machine, while observing the candy store. We see SAL leaving the store.  He crosses to his car, nea the RUSSO car.  As he passes it, he sees RUSSO locked in embrace with a lady in a babushka.  As SAL drives off, we get a closer look at the "LADY" in the babushka: DETECTIV JAMES DOYLE.

location: RUSSO'S CAR ON TRIBORO BRIDGE CROSSING TO WARD'S ISL

text: What the hell am I drivin' for? I'm a first grade Detective. You're a second grade guinea.
I'm wounded.  Oh, oh. SAL up ahead in the Mercury.
(at the wheel)
What?
The Mercury crossing the bridge to the Island.
He's goin' to Ward's Island.  We'll get spotted.  What the hell's he goin' there? DOYLE-RUSSO car B.G.
Maybe he's goin' to see his brother.
Or could be another drop.  I guess he gets a free ride.

A Brooklyn slum street on a morning in November.  It is about 11 o'clock and relatively quiet.  A scattering of tenement URCHINS give the street some sound and life.  Th are a couple of dark shops on the street and a bar, all appearing to be closed.  We look down the street and pick DOYLE and RUSSO coming down it, walking very quickly.  Th are heading toward the bar.  A young man is coming out - they grab him and throw him back.

The Young Man is thrown in, followed by DOYLE and RUSSO. There are about 20 or 30 PUETRO RICAN and BLACK MEN in th joint, a couple of BLACK WOMEN.  They are in all manner o dress.  Half of them are wearing shades.  The bar is nois with conversation, laughter and music.

DOYLE and RUSSO standing in the doorway, DOYLE slightly t the left, RUSSO a little behind him.  DOYLE's arms are at his sides.  RUSSO's right hand is crossed over his belt, under his jacket and on the butt of his .38, ready, waiti to back his partner's play or respond to any move within bar. DOYLE moving into the bar alone.  He pulls the plug out o the Juke Box, plunging the room to silence.

Hands on your heads.  Popeye's here! Twenty men raise hands to their heads as one.  The raggle taggle swarm plays a kind of human chicken, refusing to m until the last moment then stepping out of his way.  One the customers doesn't.
What's my name?
Doyle.
What?
Mr. Doyle.
Ever pick your feet in Poughkeepsie?

What? DOYLE raises his left arm and pushes the MAN aside.  The MAN's eyes go to RUSSO, off-camera at the door, and back DOYLE.  He doesn't resist; he gets in line with the rest them, a line formed about four or five feet from the bar, running the length of it. Close of DOYLE at the bar, holding an ashcan and skimming the metal underrailing with one finger, knocking off the magnetized key boxes into the ashcan.  He isn't even look at them.  His eyes are across the bar, staring down the customers. Close shot of the ashcan and the little metal boxes clink into it. Close shot of DOYLE, the ashcan now on the bar, opening o of the boxes, taking out the ten dollar bill, putting it the bar.

Then, opening another, taking out the glassine deck of heroin.  Then another, containing a glassine deck.  He empties the glassine envelopes on the bar into a cocktail mixer which he proceeds to shake.  The shaker is half-fil with tomato juice. DOYLE leaning over the bar toward the glaring crowd, pour the mixture into the ashcan.
Milk shake anyone? He wiggles his finger.  It is a command for THREE MEN to step forward.  The MEN do not move at first.
Move ass when I tell you. They move, shuffling, hesitatingly.  But they move -- TWO BLACKS and A PUETRO RICAN.

Put it on the bar. Hands of the THREE MEN going into pockets. Close of a miscellany of keys, coins, cigarettes going on the bar -- with two hypodermics, six or eight marijuana cigarettes, a small plastic vial of barbiturates.
(collecting the works)

All right, you three clowns step into those phone booths, you're goin' in.  Go on.  Stand in there till I'm ready for you. The three men turn and enter the individual phone booths. They stand, waiting, like contestants in the $64 Question
Everybody goes when the whistle blows. RUSSO is with another man from whom he's just taken a set works.
What's your story?
Gimme a break, Mr. Russo.  I'm in show business.
You're in show business.
S'right.
What do you do in show business?
I'm a dancer.
All right, get up on that bar and dance.
What?
Get up on the bar and show me how you work.  If I like it you don't have to go in.
You're for real?
Hey man, why don't you let the fella alone.
(a shout)
Am I talkin' to you -
No, but I'm talkin' to you.
I'm tellin' you to shut up and stand over there.
(to Dancer)
Get up there. The man climbs up on the bar.
I got no music!
Fake it.
The man goes into a fast tap dance.  But he only gets in few steps --

All right, that's enough, you're under arrest. RUSSO pulls the man off the bar, sends him into one of th phone booths. DOYLE coming down the front of the bar.  He stops before another man, who has just come out of the toilet.
What about you?  Can you stand a toss?
I'm clean.
You don't use shit?
No. (he goes for his wallet)
Did I say you could move that hand -- I'm not gonna get stuck am I?
No - no.
Cause if I do. DOYLE frisks the man.  Comes up with vial of pills and tw roaches.
Wise guy, huh?  Let's see what else you got. (to RUSSO)
- Buddy! He collars the man and shoves him towards the toilet. RUSSO, eyes moving everywhere, hand on the gun.

If I see any shit on the floor, it's yours, so keep your eye on your neighbor. Inside the toilet of the bar.  The MAN is up against the wall.  DOYLE is only inches away. The MAN is an AGENT and this is the only way DOYLE can ge immediate information from him without destroying the man cover.  Their conversation is in whispers.  And very fast
How's everything?
Everything is everything.
How come there's nothing out there? That stuff is all milk.
There's nothing around.  Nobody's holding.
I got a name - Sal Boca, Brooklyn.
Boca?
Doesn't register.
Got a wife named Angie.
No, nothing.  There's only some talk.
What?
Coming in this week, week after. Everybody going to get well.
Who brings it?
Who knows?
Where do you want it?

This side. Door of toilet.  There is a hell of a crash and slamming behind it.  Door opens and DOYLE steps out over the crump prostrate form of the INFORMER.  He has just decked the m to continue the protection of the cover.  He pauses halfw down the line as if he's speculating on beating up anothe one because he didn't get any information.  But he decide that would be futile too.
I'm goin' check on this address in the Bronx, if you're bullshitting me, it's your ass.
Tell everybody we'll be back in an hour.
(to all)
We're goin' now!  Goodbye.
Close shot of DEVEREAUX, New York harbor in the backgroun being interviewed by television reporters on his arrival the U.S. abroad a passenger ship.  He is smiling, jovial, charming.
How long will you be here?

Not long enough.  Two... perhaps three... weeks at most. Medium close shot of DEVEREAUX and THREE TV REPORTERS, as they talk, a crane moves into action behind them and lift out of hold.  LA VALLE is with DEVEREAUX as Translator an Interpreter.
Why did you come by ship, Mr. Devereaux?
The next several weeks will be very difficult and the middle of the ocean is the only place where the telephone isn't ringing all the time.
What will be the viewpoint of your documentary.
To make a Frenchman feel what it is like to be a New Yorker.
That's enough now, ladies and gentlemen.  M. Devereaux is due at his hotel in half an hour. Overhead the Lincoln comes down from the hold of the ship

A long view of the pier from the opposite (east) side of West Street, beneath the steel trusses and girders of the West Side Drive and through the forest of cars that are parked there, the jam of traffic that develops around eve unloading vessel.  It is a view that takes in the front e of the Lincoln inching off the pier.  HENRI DEVEREAUX at wheel, turns to his right.  We watch until the point of v on the sidewalk.  ALAIN CHARNIER and PIERRE NICOLI are standing there watching.  When the car (off-camera) turns east on the way to the garage, NICOLI glances to CHARNIER CHARNIER does not look back.

Close shot of WALTER SIMONSON at desk in the large square office he occupies as a Lieutenant of Detectives in charg of the Manhattan Narcotics Bureau.  He is the immediate superior of RUSSO and DOYLE, head of the 200-man narcotic squad that polices Manhattan.
(with coffee cup)
All that is great -- but you guys work Bed-Stuy.  You're not supposed to be in Ridgewood. DOYLE, RUSSO and SIMONSON
Detach us.  Let us have a shot at it, at least until we see if there's anything here or not. Everybody wants Weinstock, right? So maybe here's a lead.  We deserve it.

You couldn't burn a three-time loser with what you're bringing in here.  You know you stiffs could run yourselves an entrapment rap. The guy has done nothing -- Brooklyn is full of Candy Store guys with two cars who like to go to nightclubs.
Put this little candy hustler together with Joel Weinstock and it could be we stumbled into a big score.
(moves to window)
Big score!  He's dealin' a few bags here and there on the side.
Simonson, I wouldn't be infringing on your coffee break if I thought he was a nickel and dimer.
Your hunches have backfired before, Doyle. DOYLE, close, no comment. Back to SIMONSON.
(moves back to stand at desk)
Jimmy, what the hell's happening with you lately? (pause)
You got more collars than any Narc in the bureau.  What was it.  Over 100 last year?  Terrific.  But who?
You stop and shake down a bellboy because he's got three joints in his sock.  You hit a high school kid in short pants who looks like he's got a twitch. RUSSO.  Getting it back on the track.
(moves in to desk)
We got information that there's no shit in the street -- it's like a desert full of junkies with a big score coming in to make everybody well.

This could be it, Walter.  This Candy Store guy, putting on a big show in a fancy nightclub with known connections all over him. Then on our own, after working the whole day and night, we tail him out to Brooklyn and sit on him for a week practically, and who do we come up with?  Joel Weinstock. (he leans forward)
You gotta let us have it.
(pause, he turns to RUSSO)
You really believe all this crap?
I go with my partner. A pause.
What'll it take?
First a wire.
Two wires.  One on the store and one on his house.
You know I have to get a court order for wiretaps.
Try... okay?
We know you can do it, Walter. They start to leave. Close on SIMONSON.
Popeye... Close on DOYLE at the door.  RUSSO beside him. Back to SIMONSON
You still pickin' your feet in Poughkeepsie?
RUSSO on phones -- checking notes on SAL.  DOYLE reading comics on cot.  Tape machine clicks on -- tape is activat RUSSO sits attentively.
Shot of wire.

What's this crap.  I just          (He raps on table spoke to my wife and she           with a coffee cup. says you're raisin' me a           Doyle gets up.) halfa cent on the cups.        C'mere and lissen to your big connection.

WHOLESALER                (DOYLE comes over) (V.O.)                He's fightin' with somebody Yeah, well you know I          about a halfa cent. shoulda raised this here a long time ago.  We got a                DOYLE inflation period...            How we gonna keep Simonson from hearin' this?

I got your inflation.  I can            RUSSO get the same cups on Delancey  If he does, we'll be back Street for what I been         Bed-Stuyvesant tomorrow. payin' you for the last year -- That's all I gotta do with you guys -- next time it'll be two cents on the cones, then two cents on the seltzer --
C'mon Sal, I got my orders, too --
Well, if you can't do better than that, you can stick the cups.

location: AUTO GRAVEYARD, (HUNTS POINT AND EAST RIVER)

text: HIGH ANGLE: Close shot of CHARNIER, MARIE and LA VALLE walking slowly together toward the camera.  They are at t auto graveyard and the scene of an auction of cars towed New York streets by the Police Department.  About twenty other men are walking around, looking at the cars. A POLICEMAN blows a whistle and the prospective car buyer gather around the auction trailer in the b.g.
There are four auto graveyards like this one in the other boroughs, handling about a thousand vehicles a month.  Those that aren't claimed are auctioned here once a month.
Just for mistakes of parking?
No.  Many are involved in crimes and confiscated... or just abandoned. This is, as you know, your prime source of scrap metal, M. Charnier.
(off camera)
Darling, may I have this one? Medium close shot MARIE, standing next to an LTD.
It looks so lonesome here. CHARNIER and LA VALLE approach her.
It would look even more lonesome in our garage.

Within the large trailer, about TWENTY MEN are seated at long benches to each side.  Some are standing to the rear At the front, an AUCTIONEER stands at a lectern.  To his left sits a CLERK at a small table.  The AUCTIONEER wears sweater and hat.  The buyers are tough types, young and o All have inventory lists.  The atmosphere is informal.  T CHARNIERS and LA VALLE enter the trailer at the back.

Every car sold today must be removed at the purchaser's own expense.  We have no keys or anything to start the vehicles with. You buy 'em as you see 'em and where you see 'em.  All right, the first car offered is Number 24398. A Plymouth sedan.  Do I hear fifteen dollars? The bidding goes up to forty dollars.  A large BURLY MAN wins the bid.  He goes up to the CLERK and accepts the bi of sale.
We go to 24399 -- A Pontiac Station wagon.  Do I hear ten dollars?
(aside to CHARNIER)
Notice he will never mention the year of the car.

I got a fifteen dollar bid going... Do I hear anymore... Eighteen... who'll say Eighteen? Twenty... Twenty-three... Anymore... Twenty-five.  Twenty-five once -- Do I hear twenty-eight... All right, last call for twenty- five... Close shot of CHARNIER
(aside of LA VALLE)
And these are the cars we're buying for shipment? Close shot of CHARNIER, MARIE and LA VALLE.  They are fac the AUCTIONEER.
Yes, sir.  That man in the dark jacket is our buyer. Close shot of THE BUYER, LOU BOCA.  He is very active and wins the present bid.
DOYLE and RUSSO playing Gin Rummy, listening at each end one phone - breaking up.
Shot of wire.
(sleepy)
Where are you?
Takin' care o' business, honey.
Takin' care o' business -- it's after midnight.
You know I hadda meet some people tonight --
-- Well finish all your meetin' people and get back here now -- and bring a pizza with you.
Where'm I goinna get a pizza this time o' night?
Well try, okay?
I don't know where I'm gonna find a pizza joint open.
Sal --
Yeah?
Don't forget anchovies. (she hangs up)
This broad's crazy!
Pick up CHARNIER, MARIE and MAURICE LAVALLE As the camera plays over the bridge: (in French)
It's beautiful.
It was built in 1917 - and was one of the two heaviest bridges in the world.  The arch is still the largest in the world.
Who financed it?
Two railroads as part of a connecting railway which provided passage from New England to the South.  It was actually the first railroad through New York City.
Why is it called Hellgate?
The river at this point is the most dangerous on the East Coast.  Years ago, hundreds of ships went down here.
If this bridge were in Europe, it would be on every tourist's sight- seeing list.
Most New Yorkers never notice it - most Americans have never heard of it.
Look how gracefully they conceived that arch.  Like a bowstring.  It was built from both ends.  With no support in the middle.  Beautiful.
Mmm.
Alain is the only man I know who can become as enthusiastic about a bridge as he can about a woman.
Not any woman, Marie.  Just one.
CHARNIER, MARIE and LA VALLE walking. (NEAR GARAGE)

I'm afraid the rest of Ward's Island isn't nearly as romantic - a pollution plant, a hospital, a training school for garbage men and that area over there, where the old cars are kept, prior to being processed for shipment to, among other places, The Charnier Shipping Company, of Marseilles, France. (NEAR CREMATORIUM)
What is that old building?
Oh, it's been abandoned for years.
What was it?
It was a crematorium.
For garbage?
For dead bodies.
DOYLE on phones.
Allo... Salvatore...
Who's this --
... Salvatore?... RUSSO enters with a bag of sandwiches and cigarettes.  DO waves him to the phone.
... Oh... yes... yeah...       Who is it? hello... this is Sal... How are ya?                                 DOYLE Sounds like a foreigner...
Very well... you meet me                RUSSO Wednesday at the hotel...          (listening at the Okay?                              other phone) French... It's a Frenchman...
Good... good... great!                  DOYLE This is what we been waitin'
CHARNIER (V.O.)       for -- the stuff is here! Will I expect you?             It's here!
What time?
Twelve o'clock... yes...

Yes -- The phone clicks off. DOYLE and RUSSO round each other and jump up and down lik two kids. INT. WHIP GIRL'S APT. Close shot of NICOLI's face.  He's being whipped, and is caught in an ecstasy of pain and pleasure.  The tempo of strokes rises.  Suddenly it reaches a crescendo and he screams out in orgasm. Close, full-length shot of a nude BLONDE GIRL, wearing on black boots and silk panties.  She's walking away from th camera, throwing aside a small cat-o-nine-tails flagellan whip.  We can hear NICOLI's heavy breathing until the gir speaks as she moves toward a couch. Medium close shot of NICOLI, tying his tie shrugging into overcoat. Medium close shot of NICOLI, looking at the bills with a pause to sort out the currency differences, then taking o five twenties. Close shot of the WHIP GIRL taking the five then moving u to the look of annoyance and disappointment on her face.
You're Fifty Dollars short. The look of anger turns to one of consternation as NICOLI reacts to her.
M'sieru - the tab for this scene is a hundred and a half. (he moves to door)

Hey Frenchie - if you don't come up with the scratch, you're gonna run into my man downstairs. Medium close shot of NICOLI advancing on the WHIP GIRL as she backs away and begins to cringe.  He grabs her and hu her back across the couch. Close shot of the GIRL.
Don't hit me.  Don't.  Please. We hear the door slam as she sobs.
You filthy faggot sonofabitch.
Close shot of two pro football players smearing each othe on the field, others falling on top of them. Medium close shot of DEVEREAUX at a Movie-ola working out his narration (DIALOGUE IN FRENCH)

This is the new American religion, professional football.  It is where everybody goes instead of church on Sunday to express that peculiar American taste for bloodshed and violence. Several close shots of the violent action. Intercut with faces of the crowd. Close shot of DEVEREAUX.
These men, playing a "game" - make more money each year than many important business leaders, artists or government officials. (zoom out)
It tells us something about this country and how its men live, or go to war with a smile, and sometimes die without a cause. The phone rings - it is CHARNIER.
It's for you - Alain Charnier. Hold close up of DEVEREAUX.

In Lower Manhattan.  There are SIX or EIGHT MATRONS still there, stevedores and truck drivers.  Most of them are clustered at the far end of the bar, where MUTCHIE, a gra haired gone-to-paunch Irishman with spectacles as thick a pop-bottle bottoms stands behind the mahogany bar.  The cluster of customers is involved in a typical New York saloon argument. DOYLE is ignoring the debate and watching the television. He is approached by a small MAN in a long coat and baggy suit with suspenders.  This is JESUS THE BOOSTER.
Hey, Bo.
Hiya, Jesus.
Can you use a new suit for Christmans?
Whatta you got? JESUS reaches into his trousers and pulls out three suits (jackets and pants).  They are of the latest style and color, and still on hangers!
Whatta you?... a 44... 46? DOYLE examines one of the jackets.
Where'd you get this fag shit?
This is what the tough guys are wearin'.  You know I only steal from the best.  It's Bonwit Teller.
Pass.
Forty dollars -- was $250.
Whyn't you get it dry cleaned and burned. JESUS blends into the crowd and we pick up the dialogue o MUTCHIE and his cronies, BAD EDDIE, LEE and PUGGY.
A big man could alluz beat a little man.  That's why Wilt Chamberlain could murder Jim Brown if they ever fought.
No chance.  Brown'd kill him.
Chamberlain's seven foot tall, right?  He's got a twelve-foot reach.  It's geophysics.  He's punchin' down on you with leverage. He cave your chest in.

Best I ever seen was The Rock.  He was the calmest and the meanest. Guys like Sugar'd be pukin' before a fight.  Jake LaMotta'd be pukin'. Marciano was calm like he was goin' to church.  What about the night he fought LaStarza?  He hit him so hard he broke the blood vessels in LaStarza's arms.  He was the strongest meanest bastard ever lived.
Hey, Mutchie, give us another bullet. MUTCHIE pours him a straight Scotch in a shotglass.
Blackjack Burns coulds been the greatest ever --
-- He was a stone tanker.

That's right, he couldn't fight legit.  One night at the Garden about 1950, '51 -- he fought either Jake LaMotta or Gus Lesnevich, I think it was -- he took one o' those cream puff punches in the sixth -- the laziest left you ever seen -- missed him entirely.  Down goes Blackjack without even workin' up a sweat and the whole Garden gets up in its feet and I swear to Christ, everybody starts singin' "Dance With Me Henry."
I fought a guy in Cleveland once. I knew he was a dirty fighter so I stick a crowbar in my crotch. Right here.  Second round he gives me a shot -- Boom -- he breaks his hand, the fight's over.
Fuck it, I like nitroglycerin, that's my game.
What about you, Doyle?  Who's the best fighter you ever seen?
(a few drinks behind him)
Willie Mays.
Willie Mays?!
With a baseball bat!  One swing! Knock your fuckin' head off. TIME LAPSE.  The DRINKERS are gone.  MUTCHIE is at the ba cleaning up.  DOYLE is in the open adjoining kitchen area cooking breakfast.
What ya doin' out so late?  Hidin' from the cops?
I hear the health department is going to close this joint for selling dirty beer.  I come by to help you carry out your money.
They'll close you down if they ever get a look at those busted-valise broads you run with.
You want some eggs.
Why not?
(looking around for bacon)
Hey, Mutch!  You want bacon?
Yeah!
(rattling pans, looking around)
Where the hell is it?
Where the hell do you think it is, potato head? DOYLE opens the door to the icebox.

No wonder there's so many Mafia around.  Ya couldn't find a Puerto Rican in Spanish Harlem. TIME LAPSE.  Almost morning.  Close on DOYLE and MUTCHIE eating bacon and eggs.  MUTCHIE is standing behind the ba as he eats, DOYLE is sitting in front of it.  They both h a bottle of beer.

I got this little chick I'm tryin' to hit on.  She's about 20, 21... I take her to Jilly's last night and she's tellin' me about how she wants to settle down one day, get married... I says, "Hey, this is 1971, baby, I'm just a dirty old man lookin' to score with some pussy."
Strike out, eh?
Yeah.  In the late innings.  Ya look like a night's sleep wouldn't kill ya.
A piece of ass wouldn't kill me.
When ya go back on?
Morning.  Sometime.
Whyn't ya stretch out on the pool table for a couple hours.  The kid comes in at six will wake ya.  A couple eggs and a beer is cheaper than keepin' a dog around the joint.

Close of DOYLE going to his car.  He stops for a light. DOYLE is red-eyed and in need of a shave.  He fidgets through his pockets looking for a cigarette but doesn't f one.  As he drives along a GIRL CYCLIST comes into view alongside. Our view is DOYLE's view of her long, lean tapered legs. he looks further, and DOYLE always looks further, he will see there is a bra-band sweater covering her well-formed breasts.  The pendulous swing is there as she bends over handlebars. Close front view of DOYLE looking back to the light, then back to the legs. Close outside view, the cyclist, of DOYLE leaning out the window with his badge in his hand.
You got a pedaller's license?
What?
You're under arrest.

Medium close shot of RUSSO and SIMONSON.  PHIL KLEIN, a federal narcotics agent, is reading aloud from an article the New York Daily News.  MULDERIG is listening and sippi coffee. Close shot of BILL MULDERIG, a Fed narcotics agent.
Whatta you got -- four more years, Walter? Medium close of SIMONSON and RUSSO
Three. Close shot of MULDERIG.
Christ, by the time you get out all this shit'll be legal. Wide shot of room, taking in SIMONSON, RUSSO, MULDERIG an PHIL KLEIN.  SIMONSON hands BUDDY a stack of warrants.
(rises, to RUSSO)

The judge gave you ten days on these.  Klein and Mulderig will be sitting in for the Federals.  Tell Doyle they'll make all the buys, and that they're to be kept informed of everything that goes down. SIMONSON turns to MULDERIG.
You know Doyle, don't you Bill? Close of MULDERIG.
(rises)

Sure, I know Popeye.  The Master of undercover, whose brilliant idea of disguise is to limp into a room on his left foot and limp out on his right.  Whose brilliant hunches cost the death of a good officer -- Close of RUSSO
If that's how you're coming in, why not stay home and save us all a lot of grief. MULDERIG, close.
That's just my opinion. RUSSO, close.
Whyn't you shove it up your ass!
Long shot of RUSSO approaching housing project group of buildings.  This is where DOYLE lives.
RUSSO rings the bell.  No response.  He knocks.  Again nothing.  He hears a shower working inside the apartment.
Popeye. No answer.
Popeye.
(off, weakly)
Yeah.
It's Cloudy.  Open the door.
(off)
I can't.
Why not?
(off)

Let yourself in. RUSSO reaches into his jacket pocket and gets a celluloid card, his PBA card, which he slides into the door at the lock.  He gives it a juggle and the lock is free but the door moves grudgingly.
The door to DOYLE's apartment, a close view from inside. There's a bike propped against it and BUDDY RUSSO is tryi to push it open from the outside.
(behind door)
What the hell you got holding the door? The bike teeters and falls with a crash and RUSSO comes i the room puzzled, exasperated.
DOYLE is anklecuffed to the bedpost at the foot of the be
What happened to you?
(sleepy)

The crazy kid handcuffed me to the bed.  With my own cuffs. The shower goes off.  RUSSO puts the bike upright on its stand and squeezes the horn, which makes a loud beep. The BIKE GIRL appears in the bathroom door, wrapped in a towel.

Oh! RUSSO sees key on dresser - tosses it to DOYLE.  There ar clothes all over the place, the GIRL's cycling outfit, DOYLE's pants and shoes and socks.  The decor is complete impersonal.  RUSSO looks up.
(looking at scrapbook on dresser)
You oughta get plastic covers for this stuff like I did - your scrapbook's a mess like everything else in your life. RUSSO goes to chair.
Gimme my pants. RUSSO, who is half sitting on them, pulls the pants loose and hands them to DOYLE.
You got the warrant?
(sitting)
We also got Bill Mulderig and Phil Klein. Close on DOYLE, buttoning his pants.
What do we need those pricks for? Medium close on RUSSO picking around through the clothes, coming up with a pair of panties.  He holds them out.

Because by actual count our bureau has exactly nine hundred eighteen dollars and fifty-four cents to make buys and Mulderig's Feds can get all of Uncle Sam's money he wants by just asking. DOYLE sitting on bed, strapping the holster on his ankle. He checks his gun.
Throw 'em in the bathroom, will you? How good are the warrants?
(on the move down hall, at bathroom door)
Sixty days.  Here.  Don't mention it.

DOYLE is checking various items that go in his briefcase notebook, handcuffs, book of laws, field reports, pencils binoculars, candy bars, etc. Medium close shot of RUSSO looking toward the bathroom do

Hi! RUSSO looks back to DOYLE.  There is the sound of a kicks being kicked back in place, the door opening and the GIRL leaving. Medium close shot of DOYLE tying the shoes, wincing.  Loo up to the departing GIRL.
Drive carefully!
Close shot of BILL MULDERIG in back seat.  BUDDY is in front, next to DOYLE at the wheel.
Strictly small potatoes. We can see DOYLE working to keep up with the black Mercur as they cross the Brooklyn Bridge in fairly heavy traffic The Mercury cuts around in and out, DOYLE plunges after h
You really know how to pick 'em, Doyle. RUSSO turns his head in anger.
Still wearing your gun on your ankle? No answer.
Somebody told me the reason you did that was so's when you met a chick and rubbed against her she wouldn't know you were a cop. No answer.
I said that was bullshit.  It must be some kind of fast-draw gimmick or something.
Knock it off, Bill.

He's gettin' too far ahead.  You're gonna lose him. DOYLE cuts into the next lane to a lot of horn-blowing an comes to a dead, screeching stop.  DOYLE sits up sharply erect in the seat, craning to see where SAL is going.  He throws open the door and hurls himself out.

Rear medium close shot of DOYLE climbing up on the side o the car to look ahead, then jumping down and running off. DOYLE running as hard as he can. Medium close side shot of SAL turning off the bridge onto the FDR Drive, moving quickly and smoothly uptown. DOYLE running to a stop, and staring ahead.  Breathing ha horns are blowing on the bridge and they drown out the wo as he curses, "Dirty Sonofabitch."
RUSSO is on the blower.
Phil -- it's Cloudy -- we lost him -- Static comes over the two-way radio.
KLEIN is parked on Pearl Street below the Brooklyn Bridge
He just got off the Bridge - He's all yours if you can find him. Sonofabitch! KLEIN starts his car.

location: A PARKING GARAGE IN THE EAST 40'S

text: SAL emerges from the garage and heads toward Madison Aven He passes a man looking in a store window, PHIL KLEIN. KLEIN follows him.
SAL stops abruptly at the corner and turns around.  KLEIN forced to pass him and cross the street. SAL crosses the street to his left, at a right angle to K

SAL moving north on Madison Avenue.  He is walking in a triangular trap of foot surveillance.  We begin to learn this when we fall back twenty feet behind SAL and pick up the figure of JIMMY DOYLE, moving at exactly the same pac While he keeps looking forward after SAL, he also looks regularly to the left, across to the West side of Madison where we quickly zoom in on the figure of BILL MULDERIG, is on an even line opposite SAL and moving almost precise in step with the subject of their surveillance.  MULDERIG keeps an eye on SAL but is also glancing north ahead of S to BUDDY RUSSO, who is 20 or 30 feet ahead of SAL, thus forming the triangle of the A-B-C tail. SAL bobbing along. DOYLE following. MULDERIG keeping pace. RUSSO up front. SAL suddenly turning East at the Northeast corner of 46th Street, the block occupied by the Roosevelt Hotel. MULDERIG yanking at his right ear. RUSSO spinning around, hurrying back toward the corner. DOYLE turning East at the Southeast corner of 46th Street RUSSO coming around the corner looking to DOYLE. DOYLE indicating the Roosevelt entrance with his chin whi MULDERIG comes up to join DOYLE. RUSSO moving quickly into the Roosevelt entrance on 46th Street between Madison and Vanderbilt.
Roosevelt lobby stairs with ALAIN CHARNIER, PIERRE NICOLI SAL greeting.
Excuse me.
(he is moving through the jam they form on the stairs)
Excuse me. We move into the lobby of the Roosevelt and then spin aro quickly, to watch CHARNIER, NICOLI and SAL moving upstair and out the door.

A distant view from the Northeast corner of 46th Street a Madison Avenue of the Roosevelt Hotel marquee and the thr men under it, CHARNIER, NICOLI and SAL.  They are in anim conversation. DOYLE and MULDERIG on the point-of-view corner across Madison, MULDERIG with his back to the camera, DOYLE talk and watching over Mulderig's shoulder. Close shot DOYLE's face, eyes bright with excitement. Long view of CHARNIER, NICOLI and SAL under the marquee f DOYLE's view, zooming in on CHARNIER, who continues to ta look up, then look back to SAL.
You take Sal.  I'll stick with the beard if they split.

Rear view of ALAIN CHARNIER and PIERRE NICOLI strolling slowly down Madison Avenue in the Forties. An overhead view of the pair, CHARNIER and NICOLI, includ DOYLE 20 or 30 yards behind, RUSSO across the street, eve with him. CHARNIER and NICOLI window-shopping at Walter's Electric, 49th and 3rd Avenue. RUSSO looking quizzically, puzzled, from a doorway. CHARNIER and NICOLI are engaged in a running conversation that we cannot hear.  But what CHARNIER is saying is simp that he wants to get a pack of cigarettes before they tur back and stop for dinner. RUSSO looking to DOYLE for a signal.

DOYLE already beginning to feel the cold, rubbing his han together, at the front of the place CHARNIER and NICOLI h entered, trying to figure it out as CHARNIER and NICOLI emerge, CHARNIER ripping the cellophane off a pack of cigarettes, and they turn back in DOYLE's direction. DOYLE, face to face with CHARNIER and NICOLI.  Straining hear, he picks up a few words of French.  Without losing stride he steps off the curb and cuts across the street, moving south, away from them, as they come north.  But halfway across the street, we pick up RUSSO coming in his direction, sharp enough to pick up the tail where DOYLE h to drop it.
Medium close view through window of ALAIN CHARNIER and PIERRE NICOLI sitting at a table near the front windows o small restaurant.

A long shot of street zooming in on JIMMY DOYLE who is freezing his ass off in the shadows of a doorway across t street from the restaurant.  He is dancing from one foot the other, his shoulders hunched, occasionally cupping hi hands to his ears.

A medium close shot of WAITER holding a bottle of Sainte Emillion out for CHARNIER's inspection.  CHARNIER looks, frowns, shakes head negatively. DOYLE's feet.  He's standing on one foot, the other raise and he's squeezing it with a chapped hand, as if trying t get circulation back into it.
Medium close shot of NICOLI watching the WAITER scoop coq vin onto his plate. Close shot of CHARNIER taking a large forkful of food int his mouth, chewing and nodding at NICOLI.
Medium shot of DOYLE looking up to RUSSO who comes bearin paper bag which he hands to DOYLE.
Medium close shot of RUSSO standing in front of DOYLE whi DOYLE fishes a piece of pizza out of the bag and lets it fold into his mouth, then licks his fingers.
You want the red or the white?
Pour it in your ear.
Medium close view of CHARNIER through the window of the restaurant, sipping expresso.

Close shot of the pastry tray, rows of Napoleons, strawbe and peach tarts, a frothing-frenzied rum cake, etc. NICOLI close, looking like he's about to have an orgasm, glancing toward CHARNIER and then the tray.

Close shot of RUSSO peering at the restaurant.  DOYLE's f right behind him, peering over RUSSO's shoulder, trying t drink coffee from a paper container and also moving sligh against the cold and the pain of the shoes.

Rear long view of CHARNIER and NICOLI on Madison in the Forties strolling to a corner where NICOLI is splitting f the Edison Hotel (West 46th Street) while CHARNIER goes o to the Westbury on upper Madison.  They part with a wave a nod.  Hold on them as BUDDY RUSSO comes into view, movi off after NICOLI.  DOYLE follow CHARNIER.
Close shot of the elevator floor indicator rising from 1 Medium close shot of DOYLE turning away from the elevator doors and walking toward the registration desk. Close shot of the DESK CLERK.
Yes sir?
Medium close shot of DOYLE leaning on elbow on the counte half-turned to keep an eye on the elevators.
That guy just walked in.  What's his name? Close on CLERK and DOYLE.
I'm sorry, I don't know who you mean.
(showing badge)
He got off on six.
We have four rooms and six suites on six.  There's a man in almost every one of them. Close of DOYLE.
Little shorter than me.  Well- dressed.  About forty-five or fifty with salt-and-pepper hair, a beard. Close of CLERK.  Thinks it over.
There's nobody like that on six.
Perhaps he's visiting a guest.
No, I figure he stays here.  Where's your registration? CLERK gets out registration log book, goes through list a DOYLE waits.
There may be two... no, three who could fit it.
Names.
A Mr. Paul Ganapolos, he's here alone.
Where from?
Des Moines.
What's he do?
Businessman.  Owns a department store in Des Moines, I think. DOYLE is taking down the information on a pad.
Mr. and Mrs. Alain Charnier, would be another.  He's in shipping.
Yeh?  Who else?
And a Mr. Michael Lowenstein, I don't know what he does.
This Charnier guy.  He's in shipping?
I think so.  But they're in Room 408.  On the fourth floor. Close of DOYLE.
Where's he from?
Marseilles.
(gives him a dumb look)
That's in France.
Yeah, I know.

Medium close shot of DOYLE standing in another doorway, t one in Madison Avenue, opposite and a little up the stree from the Westbury.  It is about 2 o'clock in the morning there's not much traffic.  DOYLE looks like a man almost tired to stand.  We hear a car pull up (off camera).

View from the front seat of a sedan of DOYLE falling into the corner of the back seat.  RUSSO reaches across the se from the camera to hand DOYLE a brown paper container of coffee.  He opens it between his knees and scalds his mou with it.  RUSSO hands over another gift, a pint of Canadi Club.  DOYLE takes a big swig. Rear close view of BILL MULDERIG at the wheel of the car, looking at DOYLE in the rear-view mirror.

You about ready for a break? A view of MULDERIG at the wheel, RUSSO twisted around in seat, looking back at DOYLE and putting the cap back on t bottle.  When DOYLE isn't sipping at the coffee-whiskey, he's looking out the window of the car at the entrance of the hotel.  He looks beat.
The guy's a frog -- I'm pretty sure. Also he made me.  Stayin' on four but went up to six -- cute.
The other guy's a frog too.  Checked in at the Edison.  Had a hooker sent up.
Christ you should o' collared him right there.
Who's on him?
Phil Klein.
What about Sal?
We put him to bed for the night.
Why don't you do the same, Doyle? You look like shit.
(to MULDERIG)
Look.  My partner and I found this case and I don't want no Feds screwing it up.
Case?  So far I haven't seen a damn thing.
Bill, keep shootin' your mouth off and I'll knock you into the middle of next week. RUSSO, close.
Jimmy, cool it.  Nothin's goin' down tonight.  Cop a few zzz's while you can. Close shot, DOYLE.

Close shot of CHEMIST with a small lab layout spread in front of him -- burner, test tubes, etc.  The MAN's weari an ordinary business suit and both the table and the background indicate that this is not a lab, but somebody' library or den -- and a fashionable one, with photos, a signed picture of Lyndon Johnson, etc., on the panelled w The CHEMIST is running a Thiele test on a small mound of powder.  Heroin from CHARNIER's shipment. Medium close shot of JOEL WEINSTOCK and SAL BOCA sitting opposite the CHEMIST.

SAL has a glass of beer in front of him, WEINSTOCK a bran snifter containing a splash of amber cognac.  Both are interested; SAL quite nervously. The CHEMIST immerses a capillary tube, a tiny instrument size of a needle into an open kilo of heroin. He pours a small quantity of mineral oil into a burnmeist test tube and preheats the oil over the open flame of a t alcohol lamp. He removes a 15-in thermometer from its leather case, fastens the capillary tuve (now totally immersed in the heroin) to the bulb of the thermometer with a rubber band He places the bulb, with capillary attached, into an open rubber stop and inserts the entire apparatus into the burnmeister tube, about three inches in. With a small metal clamp he holds the rig over the lamp. We watch closely with the CHEMIST, WEINSTOCK and BOCA as white heroin powder slowly, agonizingly dissolves into th mineral oil and The mercury rises slowly up the thermometer to 220 - 230. The faces of the three men are filled with wonder and anxiety.  As the mercury continues to rise they become a cheering section, rooting the hometeam home. The longer it takes for the powder to dissolve, the purer the heroin.  The mercury stops at 240!
Absolutely dynamite!  89.5 proof! Best I've ever seen!  If the rest is like this, you'll be dealing for two years on this load. Close on WEINSTOCK, relaxed, smoking a large cigar.
Retail is not my end of the business. Are you telling me it's worth the half million? Medium close of the CHEMIST.
How many kilos?
Sixty.
Six kilos at eight big ones a kilo... (he nods)
I'd say it should be able to take a seven to one hit in the street.
By the time it gets down to nickel bags it's at least thirty-two million! Medium close of WEINSTOCK and BOCA.
Thank you, Howard.  Take what's left there with you and goodnight. The CHEMIST packs his apparatus and leaves.
I guess we got a deal, eh? Medium close shot of WEINSTOCK alone, appraising BOCA.
We got a test.  A deal for half a million dollars, maybe. SAL, whose cool is easily shattered.
Joel, the man is in a hurry.  He wants the bread and he wants to go back to France.  He ain't gonna hang around and play games.  He's one o' the shrewdest cats I ever run across. WEINSTOCK, close.
What am I, a shmuck?  What's the hurry?  He could see a couple of shows and visit the top of the Empire State Building.
Joel, don't jerk me.  I spent a lot o' time settin' this one up.
So whatta you want a badge?  It's your first major league game Sal. One thing I learned, move calmly, move cautiously.  You'll never be sorry.
I been damn careful up to now.
Which is why your phone lines are tapped and the Feds are crawlin' all over you like flies.
I'm straight, Joel.  They haven't got shit on me.  Look, I'm tellin' you, he'll take the deal somewhere else.

He could go someplace else with his sixty kilos of heroin and see how easy it is to pull together a half million cash.  He wouldn't find there was any hurry to do this kind of business. SAL, a little desperate.

Look, the stuff is here.  We could set up the switch in an hour.  I'm tellin' you, Mr. Weinstock, he'll split if we don't move.  This guy is everything they say he is. WEINSTOCK taking SAL apart with his eyes over the cigar.
What about you, Sal?  Are you everything they say you are? Close of SAL's worried face.
Close side view of DOYLE driving; popeyeing right and lef looking for everything and nothing.

View over DOYLE's right shoulder through windshield of a young Black HOOKER leaning against a lamppost, smiling at passing PEDESTRIAN.  Hold on her as the car moves on, DOYLE's head turning as he continues to move with the tra Rear close view of DOYLE leaning over the back seat, look as he backs the car. Close shot of the HOOKER looking up smiling, then the smi fading. Medium close view of DOYLE and the HOOKER.
You own that lamppost?
No.
Then how come you're leaning on it. Close shot of HOOKER.
I ever bust you?
I never seen you before. DOYLE and the HOOKER.
Get your ass in the car. DOYLE looking right and left, the form of the GIRL climbi into the vehicle.  He puts surveillance hat on back seat.
DOYLE is standing at an island counter in a coffee-doughn joint.  The COUNTERMAN is paying no attention to him but instead emptying coffee from a large dispenser into a pot
You gonna wait on me or am I gonna sit here all day? The COUNTERMAN responds quickly to DOYLE's voice. Close shot of DOYLE biting into a huge jelly doughnut, th jelly squeezing out onto his fingers.
A kid pushes a broom past, getting rid of a collection of cigarette butts, etc.
Hey! Close shot of KID, about 16, looking up from the broom toward DOYLE.
(off camera)
C'mere... C'mere! Medium close shot of DOYLE and the KID, DOYLE eating and drinking.
Can you stand a toss, Hector?
What you mean?
You still dealin' shit?
Jesus, no, Doyle.  I'm clean.  I'm working twelve hours a day here. Close shot of DOYLE talking around a mouthful of doughnut

When they going to make you chairman of the board? Medium close shot of DOYLE and the KID.  DOYLE puts down coffee cup.  Waves the KID closer.  The KID moves closer, DOYLE frisks him quickly, expertly, then rips up the kid' jacket and takes a 12-inch toadsticker out of the kid's waistband. Close shot of DOYLE looking at the knife, snapping the button and watching the blade flash out.
You clean your fingernails with this. Close shot of KID.
Rather be caught with it than without it.
DOYLE, pushing button and letting the blade fall into clo position.
Yeah, I guess so. DOYLE hands the knife back to the kid.  HECTOR goes back work.  DOYLE eats.

DOYLE climbing back into his car, knees on the seat, reac over into the back. Close shot over the rear seat of DOYLE picking up the str hat, which has been jammed into the corner by the contour of the Hooker's tail.  He straightens it as much as possi and throws it under the driver's seat.

Medium shot of DOYLE on foot popeyeing up Madison Avenue the vicinity of the Westbury.  As unobtrusively as possib he's looking for the tail that should be there covering CHARNIER.  DOYLE is on the East side of the street, and t Westbury is on the West.  He pokes his head into a couple doorways, checks the cars parked at the curb, looks up to couple of the mezzanine shops along the street.  He sees PHIL KLEIN and ANOTHER AGENT talking together totally oblivious to the front entrance.  MULDERIG in a cigar sto looks to his wristwatch, then goes inside the store. Close shot of DOYLE frowning, puzzled.  There doesn't see to be anybody alert.  He looks over to the hotel. Westbury Hotel entrance from DOYLE's Point of View.  CHAR steps out of hotel entrance, turns south.  The two AGENTS and MULDERIG have not seen his exit. Close on DOYLE in a doorway. CHARNIER, carrying an umbrella, strolling blithely down t street, in DOYLE's direction but on the opposite side of street.  Zoom in on his face, reflecting no concern, no problems, then zoom back to DOYLE's position.  Pan to the hotel entrance as DOYLE looks for somebody else.  Where t hell is CHARNIER's surveillance? Very quickly, DOYLE's nervous glances. CHARNIER close. A long view of the street.

CHARNIER moving along. The hotel entrance. Close shot of DOYLE going through the glancing movements, his eyes showing CHARNIER getting farther and farther dow Madison Avenue.  But there's still nobody following him. Medium close shot of DOYLE scrambling out of the doorway moving down the street after CHARNIER. Rear view of CHARNIER stopping at a newsstand, buying a c of the Times. DOYLE in a doorway, peering out and down the street. Medium close front view of CHARNIER strolling along, glan at the headlines of the Times, an umbrella hooked over hi left forearm as he walks. Close shot of CHARNIER's polished shoes, moving quickly d subway entrance stairs.  Hold on the empty stairs.  Then DOYLE's painful, scuffed shoes, follow.

Close shot CHARNIER standing on the subway platform, look at the Times, glancing toward the tracks and the rumble o train in the distance. Side rear view of CHARNIER close in the foreground, DOYLE moving into view in the background, not looking toward CHARNIER, keeping his face turned mostly away from the Frenchman. Long shot of the platform.  DOYLE right, CHARNIER left as the train pulls in.  CHARNIER is folding up his paper to board.  DOYLE is moving toward the train.
CHARNIER getting on train toward camera. Close side shot DOYLE getting on train, leaning over to l after CHARNIER's movements.
CHARNIER getting off train. DOYLE puzzled, hesitating, then getting off his car. Long shot of CHARNIER opening the Times again.
Medium shot of DOYLE moving quickly to phone booth agains the wall. DOYLE close, barking into the phone.
I'm sittin' on Frog One. MULDERIG in phone booth at Westbury.
Yeah, we got the Westbury covered like a tent.

The Westbury?  Balls.  I got him down at the subway at Times Square. What the hell's goin' on?  I make him coming right out of the hotel free as a bird.  Not a soul awake. Close shot of CHARNIER strolling past the telephone booth DOYLE looking down.

I don't care how many bartenders are sick.  I don't work in that joint.  What the hell kind of a union are you running down there? Long view of CHARNIER and DOYLE about thirty feet apart o the platform, a second train approaching.

A close view of DOYLE just inside the doors of the car sneaking a peek at the platform.  We can see that CHARNIE is not there.  He's on the train.  Suddenly CHARNIER reappears on the platform.  DOYLE steps off.

Long view from DOYLE's vantage point of CHARNIER standing with his back to the train, looking up like a man who can make up his mind, then turning to his left, away from DOY and getting back on the train.
View from interior of DOYLE car of JIMMY DOYLE nipping ba onto car.

Close view of subway doors hissing shut and an umbrella being raised at the last moment by an off-camera hand (CHARNIER's).  The doors jerk open in the safety spasm. There is a blur of the a fabric moving across the camera, blocking the view of the doors.  It is only a moment.  Wh it clears, the doors are closed again, the umbrella is go But we don't know what happened and the train isn't movin
Rear close view of DOYLE peeking into the forward car to where CHARNIER is sitting.

Quick, shocked close view of that car, revealing that CHARNIER isn't there among the twenty passengers dozing o moping in their seats.  There is a blurred flash as if DOYLE's own eyes are spinning frantically back to the windows of his own car.
Medium shot of DOYLE jumping out of train, CHARNIER jumpi back on - train takes off.

A close view of CHARNIER's face.  He is smiling directly DOYLE.  He gives him a little wave. A view from CHARNIER's position of DOYLE chasing the trai anger and hatred and frustration storming across his face

A long view from the bottom of the steep embankments abov Harlem River Drive in Washington Heights.  Sprayed along face of the cliff is a disaster -- an overturned city bus and a car with which it apparently collided.  The scene i lighted with flares.  Police rescue WORKERS and FIREMEN a scrambling up and down the face of the cliff.  They are carrying BODIES out of the bus and the car, COPS pulling them out through the windows, leading them on stretchers. There are shouted orders and some moans and cries from th wreckage.  In the foreground is LT. WALTER SIMONSON, invo in the operation, but also involved in a hassle with DOYL MULDERIG and RUSSO who are standing with him.  An officer approaches SIMONSON with a set of heroin works.
(to SIMONSON)

This belonged to the kid who was drivin' the sports car.  17 years old.  His girlfriend OD'd in the car.  We found this set of works in her arm. Medium close shot of DOYLE and SIMONSON.  DOYLE couldn't care if Rome was burning on the hill; he's only intereste in his case.
(to MULDERIG)
Where the hell was the surveillance? "Go to bed." That's all you could say.  You couldn't keep track of a bleeding elephant in a snowbank. SIMONSON, eyes on the hill, glancing to DOYLE with irrita
Jimmy, it doesn't matter anymore. If there was a deal it must have gone down by now.  We blew it!  We blew our cover and we blew the warrants --
Charnier and his wife checked out of the Westbury.  Nicoli checked out of the Edison --
This fella Nicoli's got a record in France, Walter.  He's wanted for questioning in the murder of a French cop.
I say we keep sittin' on Boca.
That's crazy.  You lost the Frog in the subway and you blew our cover. If they haven't moved already they're not gonna move now.
Walter, I can make this case if the Feds will get the hell out of my way.

With pleasure -- it's all yours. Walter, if anything develops outta this charade give me a call. Medium shot of SIMONSON, DOYLE, MULDERIG and RUSSO.  Ligh flashing around them; stretchers going by with bodies.
(to MULDERIG)
My ass.  The only reason you're in this is because you've got a big expense account for buying junk and you like to see your picture in the papers.
(to SIMONSON)
This is my case.  Get these guys off my back and let me handle it.
For chrissake, will you come off that "my case" bullshit.  This has been a whore's dream from the start. DOYLE, close.
The deal hasn't gone down yet Walter -- I know it, I can feel it. Close shot of MULDERIG

The last time you were dead certain we ended up with a dead cop. A fist, DOYLE's, comes from off-camera and connects with MULDERIG's chin.  As his head flies back. DOYLE and MULDERIG slugging and grappling with each other RUSSO leaping in to yank them apart.  SIMONSON grabbing MULDERIG's arm and holding him back. SIMONSON, close.
(roaring)
That's enough.  Get the hell out of here.
Shot of SIMONSON, MULDERIG, DOYLE, RUSSO, in a cluster.
(on way up hill, turning back)
Jimmy, you wasted two months - no collars are comin' in while you two been out jerkin' off.  Now go back to work, you're off Special Assignment.

Medium close side view of SAL BOCA's Mercury pulling to t Washington-Boston shuttle parking lot at La Guardia airpo SAL takes his ticket from the automatic vendor and drives We hold for the next car driven by PHIL KLEIN, a federal narcotics agent who is on his tail.

Medium close shot of SAL BOCA writing out the ticket orde form. Close shot of the form; SAL filling it out in an almost illiterate scrawl.  Under destination SAL fills in Washin and the camera raises its eye to a close shot of PHIL KLE on the opposite side of the counter, filling in his form. Close side shot of PHIL KLEIN standing right behind SAL i the shuttle line.
CHARNIER and an UNDERSECRETARY on the steps of the buildi shaking hands.  Two other OFFICIALS are on hand and while don't hear their conversation, their manner is extremely attentive to CHARNIER.
It has been highly informative and a personal pleasure to see you again.
I only hope we cut through to some meaningful proposals in the next month or so.  The pleasure was mine, Mr. Charnier.  When will we see you again?
Soon, probably in the Spring.
Close shot of CHARNIER.
Goodbye.
(off camera)
Goodbye.  Good trip home.

Medium long shot of CHARNIER walking across street, diagonally toward the camera, removing the identification card from his lapel. Rear close shot of CHARNIER joining SAL BOCA on the sidew and the two of them moving off together. Close shot of SAL, somewhat nervous about trying to peddl his problems to CHARNIER.
Everything's smooth.  Beautiful.  I will need a few more days though, the boys think we oughta cool it for awhile -- make sure there's no heat.
(manner outwardly pleasant)
You must take me for an imbecile. Why do you think I asked you to meet me in Washington?  I haven't spent five minutes in New York City without the company of a gendarme.
Look, I'll level with you -- I need a little more time -- I got to shift gears.
Are you having trouble raising the half million?
Hell no -- my end is covered -- my associates just feel we ought to wait for a more opportune time to make the switch. Stop, Cover.
It has to be by the end of this week.
Look, Mr. Charnier, you got to be reasonable.
It's your problem.
It's yours too! Full length shot of CHARNIER and BOCA, CHARNIER leaning o to shake his hand.
So nice to have seen you again. CHARNIER turns and walks off, leaving SAL looking after h as we zoom back to a Point of View about a hundred yards down the street. Close of PHIL KLEIN, just watching.
Close shot of MRS. CHARNIER, sitting by the window of two seats on the shuttle, looking out and babbling at CHARNIE (DIALOGUE IN FRENCH).

Look, darling, they sell these at the Smithsonian. She extracts a necklace and bracelet of shark's teeth fro an elegant alligator bag. Camera moves back to take in CHARNIER looking from the Wa Street Journal to the native craft bracelets.
Are you sure it is dead?
I'm going to put them on the cat.
That's a relief. Close shot of CHARNIER, tenderly, lovingly.
You did find something for yourself, of course. MARIE, close.
Of course.  But I am not going to tell you what it is until we are back in Marseilles. CHARNIER and MARIE.  He folds up the paper, smiling at he
